claim: In Kentucky, the electric chair has been kept in operation except for those whose capital crimes were committed prior to March 31, 1998, and who choose electrocution.

supporting.text: Kentucky's statutory framework allows lethal injection as the primary method but retains electrocution as an option for inmates sentenced before March 31, 1998.

attacks.text: Kentucky's statutory framework allows lethal injection as the primary method but retains electrocution as an option for inmates sentenced before March 31, 1998.
Retaining electrocution violates the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment.
No current Kentucky statute explicitly permits electrocution as a method of execution after March 31, 1998.
The Eighth Amendment does not apply to state-level executions under current jurisprudence.
Kentucky's legal code implicitly allows electrocution through procedural loopholes in execution protocols.
The Supreme Court has ruled that electrocution is not inherently cruel when properly administered.
Procedural loopholes cannot override explicit statutory language prohibiting post-1998 electrocutions.

supporting.text: Historical execution records show at least one post-1998 execution via electric chair for an inmate whose crime occurred prior to March 31, 1998.

attacks.text: Historical execution records show at least one post-1998 execution via electric chair for an inmate whose crime occurred prior to March 31, 1998.
The cited historical record lacks verifiable documentation or official sources confirming the post-1998 execution of a pre-1998 offender via electric chair.
The argument conflates 'capital crimes' with 'execution method choices,' ignoring that post-1998 laws may have restricted electric chair use regardless of crime timing.
Kentucky's 1998 law explicitly prohibited electric chair use for crimes committed after March 31, 1998, contradicting the claim's exception clause.
The absence of documentation does not disprove the existence of such an execution; it only questions its accessibility to the public.
Legal restrictions on execution methods do not necessarily negate the claim's exception for pre-1998 offenders who explicitly request electrocution.
The 1998 law's wording may allow exceptions for inmates with pre-1998 crimes if they opt for electrocution, depending on judicial interpretation.

supporting.text: The state constitution explicitly permits capital punishment methods including electrocution unless amended by legislation or court ruling.

attacks.text: The state constitution explicitly permits capital punishment methods including electrocution unless amended by legislation or court ruling.
Kentucky's 1998 legislation explicitly abolished electrocution as a method of execution for all capital crimes committed after March 31, 1998.
A 2008 federal court ruling declared electrocution unconstitutional due to its potential for cruel and unusual punishment.
The 1998 legislation only suspended electrocution temporarily and never formally abolished it as a legal method.
The 2008 court ruling applied specifically to lethal injection protocols and did not invalidate electrocution as a constitutional method.
Kentucky's state constitution requires explicit legislative action to remove permitted execution methods, and no such action has been taken since 1998.
The federal court ruling cited procedural flaws in lethal injection rather than addressing electrocution as an unconstitutional method.

supporting.text: No documented legal changes since March 31, 1998 indicate complete abolition of electrocution as an execution method in Kentucky.

attacks.text: No documented legal changes since March 31, 1998 indicate complete abolition of electrocution as an execution method in Kentucky.
Kentucky has not executed anyone via electric chair since 1998, implying it's no longer in practical use.
Legal documents may not reflect recent policy changes or judicial interpretations that limit electrocution use.
The absence of documentation does not confirm continued operation; it could mean hidden or unrecorded changes.
The lack of executions doesn't prove non-operation; it may reflect fewer death penalty cases post-1998.
Kentucky's legal code explicitly lists electrocution as an available method in statutes updated after 1998.
Recent legislative records show attempts to replace electrocution with lethal injection, contradicting claims of no changes.
State officials have acknowledged maintaining electric chair infrastructure post-1998 despite no executions.
The number of death row inmates is irrelevant; the method's availability depends on legal status, not usage frequency.
Statutes mentioning electrocution may include procedural limitations rather than active operational status.
Legislative attempts to replace electrocution do not equate to formal abolition or operational discontinuation.
Infrastructure maintenance alone does not prove active operation; it could be symbolic or ceremonial.

supporting.text: Kentucky's death penalty statutes from the late '90s explicitly mention electrocution as an available method alongside lethal injection.

attacks.text: Kentucky's death penalty statutes from the late '90s explicitly mention electrocution as an available method alongside lethal injection.
Kentucky's death penalty statutes from the late '90s did not mandate the use of the electric chair; they only listed it as an option without ensuring its operational readiness.
The availability of electrocution in statutes does not equate to its continued operation; Kentucky has not used it since 1999 due to technical failures.
The statutes explicitly allocated funds for maintaining the electric chair, indicating operational intent despite not mandating its use.
Kentucky's official records show that the electric chair was still functional and available until 2006, contradicting claims of technical failures.
Funding allocation does not guarantee operational status; maintenance records show neglect post-2000.
Official records may not reflect actual usage; some sources indicate continued availability beyond 2006.
